content.text: Lay the pendulum next to the rule and use the pen to make a mark on the string so that the distance \(L\) is \(0.180 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1
Set up the apparatus, fixing the string in the split bung so that the string is just touching the wooden rod at the mark you have made
Fig. 1.2 shows a side view and a front view of the apparatus
The centre of the bob should be approximately 5cm above the bench
The distance \(x\) between the bottom of the bung and the centre of the bob should be approximately 55cm
The mark on the string should be level with the centre of the rod
Measure and record the distance \(x\)
Move the bob sideways through a distance of approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\) , as shown in Fig. 1.3

Release the bob and watch its movement. The bob will move to the right and then to the left again completing a swing, as shown in Fig. 1.4. Let the pendulum swing to and fro, counting the number of swings
Measure and record the time for at least 10 consecutive swings
Record enough readings to determine an accurate value for the time \(T\) taken for one complete swing
Reduce the distance \(x\). Keep \(L\) constant, by adjusting the height of the wooden rod if necessary. Repeat **(a)(iii)** and **(b)** until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(T\)
Include values of \(\sqrt{x}\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(T\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\sqrt{x}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
The quantities \(T\) and \(x\) are related by the equation
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants
Using your answers from (d)(iii), determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\)
Give appropriate units
In this experiment, you will investigate how the motion of a pendulum whose swing is interrupted depends on its length
Place the board on the bench
Place the block with attached masses on the board, and attach the newton-meter as shown in Fig. 2.1
Gently pull the newton-meter until the block just starts to move
Measure and record the reading \(F_0\) on the newton-meter, at the instant the block just starts to move
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(F_0\)
percentage uncertainty = .........
Calculate \(\mu\) where \(\mu = \frac{F_0}{W}\)
W is the value of the weight of the block and masses written on the card
Place the board and supporting block as shown in Fig. 2.2. The longer edge of the supporting block should be vertical
Using the protractor, measure and record the angle \(\theta\) between the board and the bench
Using your values from (a)(v) and (b)(ii), calculate \((\sin \theta + \mu \cos \theta)\)
Place the block with masses on the board and attach it to the newton-meter, as shown in Fig. 2.3
Pull the newton-meter until the block just starts to move
Measure and record the reading \(F\) on the newton-meter
Place the supporting block as shown in Fig. 2.4 with a shorter edge vertical
Repeat (b)(ii), (b)(iii) and (c)
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(F\) and \(\theta\) is
where \(k\) is a constant and \(\mu\) is the value calculated in (a)(v)
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
In this experiment, you will investigate how the force required to pull a block up an inclined plane depends on the angle between the inclined plane and the bench
